comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Hi. Can you identify the regiment from their cap badges?
Stuart.

comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: Never heard of an Irishman playing  Cricket !!!  This photo was definitely NOT taken in the West of Ireland !!!

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44911068@N03] Ireland was part of Britain (UK) then and so it was not unusual to see thoroughly English games like cricket and croquet being widely played by the regiments and civilians too.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: VMA225 you're wrong you know, cricket was widely played in Ireland and that includes down the west.  The current Ireland team are very good and have taken some notable scalps, not least the Auld Enemy this year at the Cricket World Cup!!!

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44911068@N03] Here's an Irishman playing cricket. My great-grandfather.

comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: My parents emigrated to New York from the West of Ireland ( Clare and Mayo ) in 1929 and 1930.  The only sports that I had ever heard of being played in Ireland was Gaelic Football and Hurling.  I guess I was very isolated.   In New York,  the only people that I see playing Cricket are Indian's and Pakistani's and also people from the West Indies ( Caribbean ) who play at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.  There are currently 13 Cricket Pitches on the Parade Grounds in Van Cortlandt Park.  They have been playing Cricket at Van Cortlandt Park for at least 70 Years.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44911068@N03] Well now, I'm astonished at the thought of cricket being played in the Bronx! I guess we're all learning a load about our sporting preconceptions in other countries. My own mother played cricket in Dublin back in the day...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
